abstract.p: Rand D Johnson letter, commenting on Jane Smiley's Sept 12 Op-Ed article, says one reason for high US divorce rate is that Americans consistently create unrealistic expectations of what marriage should be

block.p: Re ''There They Go, Bad-Mouthing Divorce Again,'' by Jane Smiley (Op-Ed, Sept. 12):

One reason there is such a high divorce rate in this country is that we consistently conflate infatuation, sex and long-term compatibility and in doing so create unrealistic expectations of what marriage should be.
Re ''There They Go, Bad-Mouthing Divorce Again,'' by Jane Smiley (Op-Ed, Sept. 12):

One reason there is such a high divorce rate in this country is that we consistently conflate infatuation, sex and long-term compatibility and in doing so create unrealistic expectations of what marriage should be.

Infatuation is the part of love that never lasts and, despite the claims of romantics, no foundation for a long-term relationship. Sexual attraction is -- for many men, particularly -- a deep-seated drive frustrated by an insistence on sexual monogamy, with predictable results. Long-term compatibility is rooted in neither of these but instead in shared values, interests and goals, and personalities that work together.
